My experience at the restaurant within Hotel Palomar was a mixed bag. While the location was undeniably convenient as a guest, the service on my first night was marred by a single waiter's pretentious and dismissive attitude. 

My coworker and I arrived for cocktails, finding the host staff unavailable. We chose a small table near the bar and informed the waiter of our intention to only have drinks. Instead of a warm welcome, we received a reluctant "I guess it would be fine" and a hurried retreat. Throughout the evening, his behavior remained distant and unwelcoming, leaving us with a sense of being inconvenienced.

The situation escalated when we requested to split the bill due to company policy. This simple request was met with an air of annoyance, further compounding our negative experience. 

Determined to give the restaurant another chance, we returned the following night, ensuring that the problematic waiter was not on duty. This time, a friendly and engaging bartender named Ben completely redeemed the establishment. He was attentive, knowledgeable, and genuinely interested in creating a positive experience. Ben's professionalism and charisma were a stark contrast to our previous encounter, showcasing the difference a dedicated staff member can make. 

Furthermore, I ordered room service from the restaurant on my final night and was impressed by the quality of the food. The bacon-wrapped dates and chocolate cake were exceptionally delicious.

In conclusion, while one negative encounter overshadowed the initial impression, the exceptional service from Ben and the delicious room service left a lasting positive impression.  The restaurant possesses great potential, and it is unfortunate that a single individual's attitude nearly ruined the overall experience.

The daily special, a tantalizing $25 for 3 lbs of California Rock Crab, salad, and a choice of soup or chowder, proved irresistible. Witnessing trays of succulent rock crab being served solidified our decision.

Weaver's Way holds a special place in my heart, and I strongly disagree with some of the negative reviews I've seen. While it's not designed for quick, everyday convenience shopping, I, as a single woman, find it incredibly easy to navigate, even during peak hours. In fact, I see it as a perfect fit for singles like me because it allows me to purchase smaller quantities of items, something that's often difficult in larger chain stores like Acme.

Beyond the shopping experience, I appreciate the flexible work hours. I've had the opportunity to work in various departments, and currently, I'm contributing to the membership committee.  

Contrary to the stereotype of "tree huggers" and "earth children," the Weaver's Way community is incredibly diverse, bringing together individuals from various backgrounds who share a common commitment to ethical and sustainable practices.

What truly sets Weaver's Way apart is its focus on locally sourced produce, natural and wholesome foods free from preservatives, and competitive prices that are significantly lower than Whole Foods. I love interacting with fellow members and actively participating in both my local and global community.

While the membership fee and work requirements might seem daunting to some, I find them manageable as a single person. It's important to remember that co-op membership is a shared responsibility, and for those who aren't single, it's definitely a decision that should be made together as a family.

Ultimately, if you resonate with Weaver's Way values, it's an incredible place to shop. However, if you're looking for a purely convenient shopping experience, sticking to chain stores or visiting as a guest paying the 10% fee might be a better option.

Last year, my friends and I embarked on a girls' trip to New Orleans, choosing The Saint as our accommodation. The hotel's lobby was charming, and the bar and restaurant boasted a stylish ambiance that drew admiration.  I was already impressed by the hotel's usual amenities - a sophisticated yet comfortable atmosphere, friendly staff, and a sense of playful luxury.  

I checked in early, eager to tackle some work before my friend's arrival. I settled into my room, ordered room service, and focused on my tasks for a solid four hours. After wrapping up my work, I ventured out to pick up a bottle of wine and enjoy a manicure and pedicure.

My friend arrived, and we were ready to fully embrace the vibrant energy of New Orleans.  We indulged in a delicious dinner, returned to the hotel giggling, and that's when we encountered our first, and biggest, problem: a gigantic cockroach, brazenly flying across the room. I was horrified!  I immediately left the room and rushed to the front desk, terrified by the possibility of more lurking in the shadows. 

The staff assured me they would dispatch a maintenance worker, but I was unconvinced. I knew this was not a solitary pest; its boldness suggested a larger infestation. They offered us a different room, but their solution was unacceptable. The new room, they said, wouldn't be ready until 8 am. To our dismay, the new room wasn't any better. It had small spiders, dead insects in the corners, a malfunctioning TV, and even a lamp without light bulbs!

By 3 am, I was exhausted and deeply unsettled. I knew I wouldn't be staying past 8:15 am.  The thought of leaving my belongings in such a condition was simply unbearable.  I quickly booked us a room at The W, my usual go-to hotel,  for the rest of our trip.

Despite our frustration, we waited until 8 am to see if a manager would address our concerns. No one came to our room, so I went down to demand an audience. A young man approached us, apologized, and offered a refund. I accepted his apology and politely requested a full refund. He agreed and even asked us to consider returning after the necessary changes were made.  However, I politely declined. After this experience, I knew I wouldn't be back.

rewrite_original:
This new eatery deserves four stars, and with a few minor adjustments, it could easily be a five-star establishment.  Since they've just opened, it's understandable that some hiccups have occurred. Fortunately, the staff is incredibly accommodating and eager to rectify any mistakes. 

The food itself is truly excellent. While some reviewers have found the pizza lacking, I haven't had the same experience. However, I have enjoyed everything else I've tried:

* **The Quaker (Chicken Version):** This dish is a winner! I appreciate their use of chunky chicken instead of shredded. The cheese melts perfectly, and the vegetables are always fresh.  A little more seasoning on the chicken wouldn't hurt.
* **The Fries:** Crispy and flavorful, these fries are so good they don't even need ketchup—a testament to their quality!
* **The Onion Rings:** Lightly greasy but undeniably tasty and crisp. The onions stay perfectly encased in the breading.
* **Spanakopita:**  A touch overcooked this time, but the flavors were still delicious.
* **Baklava:** Absolutely fantastic!
* **Signature Salad:** The freshness of the vegetables is crucial to a great salad, and this one shines. Their balsamic vinaigrette is also excellent.
* **(Turkey) Greek Burger:** One of the best turkey burgers I've ever had! Juicy and flavorful on its own, it's elevated by a homemade tzatziki sauce that I could eat by the bowlful. My burger came with romaine instead of the advertised arugula, but it was so fresh that I didn't mind. I also requested feta, which was unfortunately omitted, but the tzatziki sauce made up for it.

Overall, this place is a hidden gem. With their commitment to quality, I have no doubt I'll be returning for more.
